source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Before irradiation, twinning occurred in the uniformly deformed region of T specimens of all materials. The amount of twinning tended to increase with grain size, and to decrease with increasing alloy content.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Bement [8] found previously that twinning was not markedly changed by irradiation

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: After irradiation at 575 K the specimens of BY material exhibited large amounts of uniform elongation for both crystallographic textures

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: The defects or loops or both were larger after irradiation at 575 K than at 375 K

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: there was some tendency for niobium to decrease the defect size

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: In deformed sections of the specimens there were cleared swaths which did not have any defects

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: In some twins in uniformly deformed material there were many irradiation induced defects

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: in others no defects could be seen even when the foil was tilted for maximum contrast in the twin

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: deformation by twinning does not remove the defects, but they are removed when slip occurs in the reoriented material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: This behavior seems to be different from that of irradiated annealed rhenium [9], where damage was always found in the twins

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: for most irradiated zirconium alloys tested at ≤ 575 K, the strain rate sensitivity is small

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: the strain to plastic instability is decreased by increasing the flow stress or decreasing the work hardenability

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: In the crystal bar and 0.5 Sn materials, irradiation increased the flow stress but did not have a large effect on work hardenability

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: hence the strain to plastic instability was small

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Irradiation also increased the flow stress of the niobium alloys, but there was generally a larger increase in their work hardenability

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: the strains before plastic instability occurred were generally larger

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: the superior plastic stability of the niobium alloys is due to the comparatively larger increment in their work hardenability

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: work hardenability decreases with increasing temperature due to the increase in the rate of recovery

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: The BS, CN, CA, BZ, and BY materials had similar structures consisting of equiaxed α grains and in the unirradiated condition they had similar work hardenabilities [13]

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk3
evidence_span: Deformation by slip produces the dislocation substructure which increases the flow stress and results in work hardening

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: In commercial Zr-2.5Nb material niobium stabilized the damage against annealing

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: niobium might also stabilize the damage against deformation

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: The damage in the BT material formed during irradiation at 575 K was more resistent to annihilation by dislocations than damage formed at 275 K

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: damage formed at 275 K

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: the alloys containing niobium should be more resistant to the damage being removed by slip bands particularly after irradiation at 575 K

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: their work hardenability will not decrease as rapidly as in the other alloys with less stable damage

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: the irradiation increment in strength is often independent of crystallographic texture, Fig. 5

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: irradiated fuel sheathing of annealed Zr-Nb alloy should undergo more circumferential strain before onset of plastic instability than sheathing of annealed Zircaloy

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: The Russian success with annealed Zr1.0Nb sheathing may be due to this feature

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: Niobium additions to zirconium promote plastic stability in irradiated material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: This stability occurs despite a high irradiation induced hardening

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: is due to an even higher increment in work hardenability

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: One marked exception occurs in Zr-0.5Nb when the grain size is about 20 μm

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: Twinning can occur without destroying the visible irradiation damage

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: Fuel sheathing of Zr-Nb alloy could show more plastic stability than the conventional Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_031_chunk4
evidence_span: the moderator to be maintained at a low temperature (~80°C)
